summary: Feature request to support flexible workflow and method naming across language SDKs to enable seamless migration. Currently, the TypeScript SDK requires workflows to be named from filenames and use an `execute` method, creating incompatibilities with PHP and Java implementations that use custom method names.
userImpact: Users migrating workflows from other languages like PHP or Java to TypeScript must rename methods and potentially restructure their code to comply with SDK conventions.
rootCause: TypeScript SDK uses fixed naming conventions (file-based registration, `execute` method) whereas other language SDKs (PHP, Java) allow custom method names via decorators/annotations.
proposedFix: Support custom method names using TypeScript decorators, or document a cross-language compatibility matrix showing naming restrictions and calling patterns.
workaround: Define workflow interfaces in other languages with custom method names and call them from Node via stub interfaces that use the `execute` convention.
resolutionDetails: The SDK team decided to maintain the `execute` method convention for consistency and rejected decorators to preserve JavaScript compatibility. Documentation of cross-language patterns was recommended instead.
keyQuote: I think it would be a rude surprise for someone hoping to migrate to TypeScript to realize that they have to change a lot of legacy workflow interfaces.
